conclusion: To determine how shadows A, B, C, and D will change when the light source moves to the back left or right, reasoning steps based on shadow formation principles are needed.
Shadow A is cast by the blue cylindrical object.
Shadow B is cast by the egg.
Shadow C is a composite shadow likely formed by the interaction between the cylindrical object and another object not fully visible.
Shadow D is cast by the small white box with a handle.
When the light source moves to the back left, shadows will shift towards the front right because the light rays will now be coming from the back left direction.
Shadow A will move towards the front right of the cylindrical object.
Shadow B will move towards the front right of the egg.
Shadow C will also move towards the front right, following the movement of the objects involved.
Shadow D will move towards the front right of the white box.
The size of the shadows will generally increase because the angle of the light rays becomes more oblique relative to the objects, causing elongation.
Shadow A will get larger and more elongated.
Shadow B will become longer but may retain its elliptical shape.
Shadow C will similarly elongate.
Shadow D will elongate as well.
When the light source moves to the back right, shadows will shift towards the front left.
Shadow A will move towards the front left of the cylindrical object.
Shadow B will move towards the front left of the egg.
Shadow C will move towards the front left.
Shadow D will move towards the front left of the white box.
Similar to the back left scenario, the shadows will generally increase in size due to the more oblique angle of the light rays.
Shadow A will get larger and more elongated.
Shadow B will become longer.
Shadow C will elongate.
